A **T-shirt** is a type of [shirt](/wiki/Shirt "Shirt") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth"), and is nearly identical to the [Hawaiian shirt](/wiki/Hawaiian_shirt "Hawaiian shirt").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

## Generation

The T-shirt makes up 0.2% of all randomly generated [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor").

## Description

While worn, a T-shirt provides no base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC").

T-shirts can be [read](/wiki/Read "Read"), which breaks the illiterate [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct") and displays a message describing the text on the shirt[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) - this message is dependent on the item's object ID, so it will remain consistent for any one T-shirt, and the text will be degraded if the shirt is [eroded](/wiki/Eroded "Eroded").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Entering a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") with a visible worn T-shirt will cause the [shopkeeper](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") to charge an extra 1⁄3 markup and buy things for 1⁄3 of the base price.

## Strategy

Like the Hawaiian shirt, T-shirts are generally employed to enchant as an additional source of AC, but are best reserved until after a character obtains protection from [polymorph traps](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap") - worn torso armor will be destroyed if they polymorph into a large form. In the early game, scrolls of [enchant armor](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_armor "Scroll of enchant armor") may be best reserved for other armor such as a [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm"), [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots") or [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves"). T-shirts are typically most worth enchanting once a character has [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), as well as solid enough enchantment on their other armor. An enchanted T-shirt may also be [wished](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for in order to top off an otherwise-complete [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit").

For characters not averse to [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling"), shirts are fairly easy to obtain with a [wand of polymorph](/wiki/Wand_of_polymorph "Wand of polymorph") (or the [polymorph](/wiki/Spellbook_of_polymorph "Spellbook of polymorph") spell for powerful enough casters) and a large pile of armor, which is most easily obtained in the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") or [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios"). The Castle's armor storeroom in particular has a 13.13% chance of containing either a Hawaiian shirt or a T-shirt. The random general store items in [Orcus Town](/wiki/Orcus_Town "Orcus Town") may also have a T-shirt among them.

## History

The T-shirt first appears in [NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0"), where it generates if the TOURIST [compile-time option](/wiki/Compile-time_option "Compile-time option") is defined. From this version to [NetHack 3.3.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.1 "NetHack 3.3.1"), there are only three possible T-shirt messages:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

- "I explored the Dungeons of Doom, but all I got was this lousy T-shirt"

  The normal T-shirt message.

- "I explored the Dungeons of Doom, and never did any laundry..."

  You are [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating") and currently wearing the T-shirt.

- "I explored the Dungeons of Doom, and couldn't find my way out"

  As above, but you are not currently wearing the T-shirt.

Many extra T-shirt messages are added in [NetHack 3.4.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.0 "NetHack 3.4.0") from a [patch by Scott Bigham](http://www.killerbunnies.org/nethack/3.3.1/tshirt.diff), and several more are introduced in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") and [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1").

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the [Tie-Dye Shirt of Shambhala](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Tie-Dye_Shirt_of_Shambhala "DNetHack artifacts") is an unaligned [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") T-shirt that can be enchanted to +7, and alters carrying capacity while worn: it confers a 1⁄2 increase while blessed, a 1⁄4 increase while uncursed, and a 1⁄4 *penalty* while cursed. The shirt also enhances charisma if worn without body armor and enhances wisdom if worn with it, and can be read to cure status properties like a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") if not covered by non-crystal body armor. Invoking the Tie-Dye Shirt confers [enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment "Enlightenment").

### TNNT (the game)

In [TNNT (the game)](/wiki/TNNT_\(the_game\) "TNNT (the game)"), the reward for completing [the DevTeam Office](/wiki/The_DevTeam_Office "The DevTeam Office") quest is the [Really Cool Shirt](/wiki/Really_Cool_Shirt "Really Cool Shirt"), an artifact T-shirt that acts as a [luck item](/wiki/Luck_item "Luck item") while carried and provides [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") while worn. Reading the Really Cool Shirt has a 49⁄50 chance of producing a random rumor according to its beatitude: true only if blessed, false only if cursed, or either if uncursed. Due to its generation method, it will revert to a normal T-shirt if left in a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), T-shirts can be made of other materials such as [leather](/wiki/Leather "Leather"), which provides some base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and may make them more valuable to wear early on. Shirt wishes are just as popular as in *NetHack* if not more so: [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials_\(EvilHack\) "Object materials (EvilHack)") and [properties](/wiki/Object_properties "Object properties") make the shirt slot valuable for characters that are not [giants](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") or [tortles](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)"). An example of such a wish is "blessed greased fixed +3 [dragonhide](/wiki/Dragonhide "Dragonhide") T-shirt of decay", with "decay" being an object property that provides [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), T-shirts can only be made of cloth. [Upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a T-shirt will produce a [striped shirt](/wiki/Striped_shirt "Striped shirt"), and vice versa.

4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [read.c in NetHack 3.3.0, line 86](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.3.0/read.c#line86 "Source:NetHack 3.3.0/read.c")

In the early game, scrolls of {{? of|enchant armor}} may be best reserved for other armor such as a [[helm]], [[boots]] or [[gloves]]. T-shirts are typically most worth enchanting once a character has [[magic resistance]], as well as solid enough enchantment on their other armor. An enchanted T-shirt may also be [[wish]]ed for in order to top off an otherwise-complete [[ascension kit]]. For characters not averse to [[polypiling]], shirts are fairly easy to obtain with a [[wand of polymorph]] (or the {{spell of|polymorph}} spell for powerful enough casters) and a large pile of armor, which is most easily obtained in the [[Castle]] or [[Fort Ludios]]. The Castle's armor storeroom in particular has a 13.13% chance of containing either a Hawaiian shirt or a T-shirt. The random general store items in [[Orcus Town]] may also have a T-shirt among them. ==History== The T-shirt first appears in [[NetHack 3.2.0]], where it generates if the TOURIST [[compile-time option]] is defined. From this version to [[NetHack 3.3.1]], there are only three possible T-shirt messages:{{refsrc|read.c|86|version=NetHack 3.3.0}} {{message|"I explored the Dungeons of Doom, but all I got was this lousy T-shirt"|The normal T-shirt message.}} {{message|"I explored the Dungeons of Doom, and never did any laundry..."|You are [[hallucinating]] and currently wearing the T-shirt.}} {{message|"I explored the Dungeons of Doom, and couldn't find my way out"|As above, but you are not currently wearing the T-shirt.}} Many extra T-shirt messages are added in [[NetHack 3.4.0]] from a [http://www.killerbunnies.org/nethack/3.3.1/tshirt.diff patch by Scott Bigham], and several more are introduced in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] and [[NetHack 3.6.1]]. ==Variants== ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]], the [[dNetHack artifacts#Tie-Dye Shirt of Shambhala|Tie-Dye Shirt of Shambhala]] is an unaligned [[artifact]] T-shirt that can be enchanted to +7, and alters carrying capacity while worn: it confers a {{frac|2}} increase while blessed, a {{frac|4}} increase while uncursed, and a {{frac|4}} ''penalty'' while cursed. The shirt also enhances charisma if worn without body armor and enhances wisdom if worn with it, and can be read to cure status properties like a [[unicorn horn]] if not covered by non-crystal body armor. Invoking the Tie-Dye Shirt confers [[enlightenment]]. ===TNNT (the game)=== In [[TNNT (the game)]], the reward for completing [[the DevTeam Office]] quest is the [[Really Cool Shirt]], an artifact T-shirt that acts as a [[luck item]] while carried and provides [[warning]] while worn. Reading the Really Cool Shirt has a {{frac|49|50}} chance of producing a random rumor according to its beatitude: true only if blessed, false only if cursed, or either if uncursed. Due to its generation method, it will revert to a normal T-shirt if left in a [[bones]] file. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], T-shirts can be made of other materials such as [[leather]], which provides some base [[AC]] and may make them more valuable to wear early on. Shirt wishes are just as popular as in ''NetHack'' if not more so: [[Object materials (EvilHack)|object materials]] and [[Object properties|properties]] make the shirt slot valuable for characters that are not [[Giant (starting race)|giants]] or [[Tortle (starting race)|tortles]]. An example of such a wish is "blessed greased fixed +3 [[dragonhide]] T-shirt of decay", with "decay" being an object property that provides [[drain resistance]]. ===Hack'EM=== In [[Hack'EM]], T-shirts can only be made of cloth. [[Upgrading]] a T-shirt will produce a [[striped shirt]], and vice versa. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Shirts]]
